TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit DataPagerFieldCollection extends System.Web.UI.StateManagedCollection

Docs.summary: Represents a collection of objects that are used by the control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks You can use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerFieldCollection> class to programmatically manage a set of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerField> objects. Note that it is more typical to define these fields declaratively instead of programmatically.
You can access the properties and methods of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerFieldCollection> class through the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager.Fields%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property. You can add, insert, and remove <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerField> objects by using the appropriate methods of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerFieldCollection> class. To programmatically retrieve <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerField> objects from a collection, do one of following:
- Use the indexer to get a single <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerField> object from the collection.
- Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.StateManagedCollection.GetEnumerator%2A> method to create an object that implements <xref:System.Collections.IEnumerator?displayProperty=fullName>, which you can then use to get items from the collection.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.StateManagedCollection.Count%2A> property gets the total number of items in the collection. It is typically used to determine the upper bound of the collection. You can add items and remove items in the collection by using the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerFieldCollection.Add%2A>, <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerFieldCollection.Insert%2A>, <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerFieldCollection.Remove%2A>, and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerFieldCollection.RemoveAt%2A> methods.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerField> object is added to the end of the collection.
## Examples The following example shows how to use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerFieldCollection.Add%2A> method to add a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.NextPreviousPagerField> object to a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control.

MemberSignature.Value: protected override object CreateKnownType (int index);
.method familyhidebysig virtual instance object CreateKnownType(int32 index) cil managed

Docs.param: The index of the type to create from the ordered list of types that are returned by the method.
Docs.summary: Creates a default instance of the type that is identified by the provided index.
Docs.returns: An object that represents an instance of a class that is derived from the class, according to the index provided.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerFieldCollection.CreateKnownType%2A> method is called internally by the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerFieldCollection> collection in its implementation of the <xref:System.Web.UI.StateManagedCollection.System%23Web%23UI%23IStateManager%23LoadViewState%2A> method. The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerFieldCollection.CreateKnownType%2A> method creates an instance of an object by using the type identified by the specified `index`, which maps to one of the types returned by the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerFieldCollection.GetKnownTypes%2A> method.

Docs.exception: The specified index is not in the recognized range.

MemberSignature.Value: public event EventHandler FieldsChanged;
.event class System.EventHandler FieldsChanged

Docs.summary: Occurs when the fields in the collection change.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerFieldCollection.FieldsChanged> event is usually raised as a result of a call to the <xref:System.Web.UI.StateManagedCollection.Clear%2A>, <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerFieldCollection.Insert%2A>, <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerFieldCollection.Remove%2A>, or <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPagerFieldCollection.RemoveAt%2A> methods.
For more information about how to handle events, see [NIB: Consuming Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/01e4f1bc-e55e-413f-98c7-6588493e5f67).
